post.title: Acknowledging “first world problems” can make you happier
post.content:
“We ran out of bottled water and now I have to drink tap water” – this is a real complaint sometimes at my house but it’s also what is known as a “first world problem” and I’m going to tell you why acknowledging them is actually good for you.

First, to explain “first world problems” to those who aren’t familiar with the term – First world problems are simply problems people in wealthy nations have, that is to say, in comparison to undeveloped nations, your problems are usually not very serious. A first world problem is, “I have to eat leftovers because I’m too tired to cook” – while a third world problem would be literally facing death due to starvation.

According to KnowYourMeme.com, the term “first world problems” was first used in 1995. A Canadian alternative rock music group called Matthew Good Band sings “Somewhere around the world, someone would love to have my first world problems,” in the song “Omissions of the Omen.” In 2005 the term was entered on the website Urban Dictionary, and it has popped up various times since then – most recently in the form of the “first world problems” meme which usually features an image of a woman crying melodramatically along with captions such as, “My treadmill is broken, so I have to go for a run outside,” “The vending machine takes quarters, but I have only twenties,” and “Can’t find the remote control, so I have to get up to change the channel.”

Chances are you run into several first world problems each day – you may even vent about them to your friends on Twitter or Facebook, (the hashtag #firstworldproblems is pretty popular), but I’m going to give you another option for dealing with them which may actually make you feel happier instead of offering you an opportunity to publicly wallow in self pity.

Next time you have a problem, ask yourself whether it qualifies as a first world problem. If it does, just that simple question may have given you perspective – already you’re feeling better. If acknowledging the fact that it’s a first world problem still hasn’t removed your desire to whine about it though, go make a meme out of it. The captions for the last three I’ve made include:

• It’s too hot outside, but the air conditioner is making it too cold inside
• I found too many good books at the library, and can’t decide which to read first
• I’m craving Chick-Fil-A but it’s Sunday

The two minutes it took to conjure these images in my head provided a moment for me to first laugh at myself and relieve some stress, but also to then realize my “problems” are not serious – that in fact, many of my problems are desirable, (I know several people who don’t have air conditioning and would not sympathize with my “too cold” complaint.) … Taking a time-out to get perspective and remember how fortunate one is, is sometimes all the solution one needs to their “problem.”

What is the most ridiculous “first world problem” you’ve run into lately? Share in comments!
